children.subject:
Ahh.
So you are saying that I wont be at a disadvantage while applying for internship for Junior summer even though I would have taken only one semester worth upper divisions but other would have taken more than that?

I was just typing this up, and it coincidentally seems to be the answer to your new query haha:

As for the impact taking certain courses has on your callback rate for generalist SWE Intern positions, it's very diminished in comparison to referrals, past experience, personal projects, and school name, in mostly that order.

Now of course, if you were applying for some specific role that required particular knowledge of say databases or operating systems, then it might be tough to get past the resume screen for those without even having taken the course, but really, most (all?) big N have generalist openings that you can apply to, and if you don't get a big N there's plenty other SWE Internships that are generalist by nature.

Just a heads-up, but both 61C and 70 over the summer sounds insane for a regular student, or even one who does well by working hard but does not have much familiarity with the content beforehand. I would not recommend taking both over the summer, if you choose to take any courses at all.

As for what you should do to increase your chances of getting an internship junior summer, the most important thing in my experience is past experience. If you haven't had any internships yet, a productive internship this summer will be conducive to attaining a higher callback rate when you apply again next year. Upper-division courses at Berkeley are mostly a deeper dive into certain sub-domains, and you most likely don't need to take as many upper-divs as you might think right now if you're trying to start off as a generalist SWE. Only take those that upper-divs whose focus may interest you and/or if you're interested in pursuing a career in those specific sub-domains. Even if you start taking upper-divs junior Spring, you'll still be able to take 6-7 upper divs by the time you're done (assuming you take 2-3 a semester), which is plenty opportunity for either breadth or depth, depending on the path you go down.
Fyi I think (not sure) it’s nearly impossible to switch into EECS unless you’re already an engineering major

My logic was that if I take 70/61C over the summer then I can take more upper div classes in my junior year.

Hence it was whether a prior internship experience holds more value or having taken more upper div classes

I think you'll find much more value in an internship than summer classes. You're more likely to get a better internship if you've had one already. Upper divs are less important for internships IMO, and if there is any upper div that is particularly relevant to your Junior year internship, you can always take that one before the job, or learn on the job.
Pretty sure an internship is 100% more effective to get you a next one than 70+61C

history.content:
Hey
I am a Sophomore who is intending to switch to EECS this semester.
As a result, by the end of this semester, I would have completed CS 61A, CS 61B, EECS 16A and EECS 16B.

I was wondering whether I should hunt for an internship over the summer (I haven't gotten one yet) or complete both/either CS70 and CS61C over the summer.

I mainly wanted to know that to get an internship during junior summer, what is more beneficial?
Prior internship experience during sophomore summer or having taken a good number of upper div CS classes to build my skill set?
(If I do not take CS70 and CS61C over the summer, then I would have to take them Fall 2020 and would only be able to take upper divs in my spring of Junior year).
history.subject: Summer Classes vs Internship
